title: General Chemicals
description: Requirements for proper management, storage, and use of chemicals in indoor agriculture operations including inventory control, safety data sheets, storage security, food grade designation, and sanitizer concentration verification

requirements.text: Are there chemical inventory logs for chemicals, including pesticides, fertilizers and cleaning and sanitizing chemicals?
mandatoryStatements: Chemical inventory log is maintained for all chemicals on site
Inventory includes pesticides used in facility or operation
Inventory includes fertilizers and growing nutrients
Inventory includes all cleaning chemicals
Inventory includes all sanitizing chemicals
Inventory is updated when chemicals are received or used
Inventory shows chemical name, quantity, and location
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly verification of chemical inventory accuracy through physical inventory count
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Monthly review of chemical inventory logs, immediate update when chemicals added or depleted

requirements.text: Are copies of all Safety Data Sheets on file and fully accessible at all times with clear indexes?
mandatoryStatements: Safety Data Sheets (SDS) are on file for every chemical on site
SDS are readily accessible to all employees at all times
Clear index or table of contents helps locate specific SDS
SDS are current versions (updated within 3 years)
Electronic or physical SDS access does not require special authorization
SDS are available in language(s) understood by employees
Emergency response information from SDS is readily available
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual verification that SDS are current, complete, and accessible
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Quarterly check of SDS files for completeness, immediate addition of SDS for new chemicals

requirements.text: Are all chemicals (pesticides, fertilizers, sanitizers, detergents, lubricants, etc.) stored securely, safely and are they labeled correctly?
mandatoryStatements: All chemicals are stored in secure, designated storage areas
Chemical storage prevents unauthorized access
Chemical storage prevents contamination of product, equipment, or materials
Incompatible chemicals are segregated
All chemical containers are properly labeled with contents
Original labels are maintained or transfer containers are properly labeled
Storage area is well-ventilated and appropriate for chemical types
Secondary containment provided for liquid chemicals where appropriate
Chemical storage area is clean and organized
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly inspection of chemical storage areas for security, safety, and proper labeling
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly checks of chemical storage conditions, immediate correction of labeling or storage deficiencies

requirements.text: Are "food grade" and "non-food grade" chemicals used appropriately, according to the label and not commingled?
mandatoryStatements: Food grade chemicals are clearly identified and segregated
Non-food grade chemicals are clearly identified and segregated
Food grade chemicals are used only for food contact applications
Non-food grade chemicals are not used on food contact surfaces
Chemicals are used according to label instructions
Storage prevents commingling of food grade and non-food grade chemicals
Personnel are trained on appropriate use of food grade vs non-food grade chemicals
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly verification that food grade chemicals are properly identified and used appropriately
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Monthly inspection of chemical storage for proper segregation, daily monitoring of chemical use practices

requirements.text: Does the operation use the appropriate test strips, test kits or test probes for verifying the concentrations of anti-microbial chemicals (e.g., product contact water, sanitizers, dip stations, etc.) being used, are they in operational condition and are they being used correctly?
mandatoryStatements: Appropriate test strips, kits, or probes are available for all antimicrobial chemicals used
Test equipment is specific to the chemicals being tested
Test equipment is in operational condition (not expired, properly calibrated)
Test equipment is used correctly according to manufacturer instructions
Testing is performed at required frequency
Test results are recorded
Corrective action is taken when concentrations are out of specification
Personnel are trained on proper use of test equipment
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly verification that test equipment is appropriate, operational, and used correctly
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily or per-use testing of antimicrobial concentrations, immediate adjustment if out of specification

capaInject: If chemical inventory not maintained: establish inventory immediately, conduct physical inventory within 7 days
If SDS missing or inaccessible: obtain missing SDS within 24 hours, establish accessible filing system within 7 days
If chemicals not stored securely or safely: immediate containment of hazards, establish proper storage within 7 days
If chemicals not labeled correctly: immediate labeling of all containers, remove unlabeled chemicals until identified
If food grade and non-food grade chemicals commingled: immediate segregation, retrain personnel within 7 days
If antimicrobial concentrations not tested or incorrect: immediate testing and adjustment, verify effectiveness before use
If test equipment expired or not operational: replace immediately, halt use of untested antimicrobials until testing capability restored
traceabilityInject: Chemical inventory records must be traceable to receipt dates, lot numbers, and usage
Antimicrobial concentration test results must be traceable to specific solutions, dates, and personnel
Chemical usage must be traceable to specific applications and batches (where applicable)
Any chemical incidents or deviations must be fully documented with traceability
